Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is assuring that students complete certificates or AAS degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) related fields; increasing opportunities for women and under-represented students; and enhancing and disseminating the Lean Internship Model within the college and other academic institutions. It is also providing on-site faculty professional development at the nearby NASA Wallops Flight Facility (WFF) and the Navy Surface Combat Systems Center (SCSC) to enhance faculty understanding of aerospace and defense industry education needs. It is building on a successful American Association of Community College (AACC) Mentor Links ReConnect project supported by NSF. The internship program initiated through that effort is being further developed and enhanced into a scalable model using LEAN principles to maximize efficiency and provide the best value and outcomes for students and industry customers.

The primary project audiences are students enrolled in AAS degree programs in Electronics Technology; Electronics Technology: Computer Technician Specialization; and Business Technology: Information Systems Technology Specialization. Other eligible programs include Certificate Programs in Computer-Aided Drafting and Design; Electronics; Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning; Industrial Maintenance Technology; Information Systems Technology; and Welding. The focus is on Career Pathways for STEM programs that provide science and engineering technicians for NASA WFF, Navy SCSSC, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and related aerospace and defense industry support contractors.

Intellectual Merit: The project is expanding and developing new internship pathways that prepare students for entry-level STEM careers. It is ensuring that local students have the opportunity to improve their technical education and motivating them to successfully complete credentials and obtain technological employment locally and in the broader world.

Broader Impacts: The project is advancing knowledge and understanding within community college STEM programs by providing a model that builds industry partnerships and results in student internships and faculty professional development. These academic and industry partnerships are promoting teaching, training, learning, and diversity in the technical workforce and positively impacting the geographically isolated, low-income, and ethnically diverse population area served by the college both academically and economically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eastern Shore Community College (ESCC), located in Melfa, Virginia, is one of numerous small, rural community colleges with limited local industry employment opportunities. A key partner in ESCC's LEAN internship project was NASA Wallops Flight Facility (WFF). WFF’s research and responsibilities center on providing a response to meet the needs of the U.S. aerospace technology interests and science research. The cluster of business/industry/government on and near WFF includes opportunities for employment in high tech, high wage, and/or high demand occupations.

The primary project goals were to:

1)     Develop internship pathways for the attainment of a certificate or AAS degree to prepare students for entry-level careers in STEM-related fields;

2)     Provide outreach opportunities for women and under–represented students to learn about STEM-related fields and increase STEM internship opportunities for both groups;

3)     Enhance and disseminate the LEAN internship process within the college and externally to other ATE Centers; and

4)     Provide on-site professional development with NASA, the Navy, and other Wallops partners towards an embedded understanding of industry needs.

Goal 1 was met by developing internship pathways based on LEAN manufacturing principles. By offering optional internship experiences, flexibility was provided for students, resources needed to fund internships were reduced, and a construct for long-term sustainability was created. The original NASA internship project funded by the ESCC Foundation was conceived as a pilot with the intent of securing external funding to maintain and expand the program. By working closely with partner organizations, students learned of other valuable internships and were assisted in application processes through guidance and preparation needed to be successful in obtaining and completing these internships.

One project objective was to demonstrate to other community colleges how to establish and sustain a successful internship program by adapting LEAN manufacturing principles to add value and reduce waste, thus treating an internship program as a process with various components, inputs, and products. This has been met through various regional, state, and national presentations.

Partner feedback from host sites, WFF Education Department, interns, and project staff was used to guide the implementation, development, and refinement for continuous improvement. The internship program is now an integral component of several ESCC programs and the value of the program has been proven to industry partners who continue to hire interns in full-time positions on a regular basis. Long-term sustainability of the program seems assured through the financial support of employers, such as MARS and Tyson Foods, and the ESCC Foundation. 

Goal 2 was met by using diversity inclusive techniques in numerous promotions and events. One specific activity was an annual Women in Technology Exposition. Speakers for this event were female, minority graduates of ESCC technical programs who became successful local aerospace industry employees. Interactive demonstrations, including welding and computer repair, were conducted by female ESCC graduates who served as mentors and role models. Another outreach opportunity conducted annually for high school students is Career Night Out; recent focus was on gender-based nontraditional enrollment/completion. The feature activity was a technology-based Quiz Bowl co-hosted by a female Career Coach and a minority faculty member. Content focused on identifying gender biases.

In addition, ESCC designed billboards, table displays, and banners, and produced videos highlighting opportunities for women and under-represented students in STEM-related fields.

Goal 3 has been met through the following:

  • NSF/ATE PI Conferences, including a showcase display, hosting a roundtables, and conducting a breakout session
  • SpaceTEC NVC meetings partner presentations
  • Virginia Community College Association Showcase
  • Leveraging Sustainable Partnerships – The Mid-Atlantic Higher Education Business & Research Conference
  • Richmond Aviation and Aerospace Workforce Plan Input Session
  • Featured session at VCCS New Horizons Conference
  • College Night in Virginia, Career Night Out, Women in Technology Expo, TAACCCT Celebrate Success Conference, Career Fairs, New Student Orientation
  • Press releases to ESCC website and media
  • Keynote session VCCS Council of Deans and Directors on the role of internships in breaking down barriers to employment
  • VCCS Workforce Development Hire Education Conference

These activities have disseminated the project and results to an estimated 3,100 individuals.

Goal 4 was met through the following:

  • Adjunct faculty member completed an Institute for Women in Trades, Technology and Science (IWITTS) class
  • Utilizing webinars and publications from IWITTS
  • Key college and project personnel attended NSF/ATE PI Annual Conference
  • Project team visited BATEC to learn about technology internship program design and working with diverse populations
  • On-site professional development at WFF RockOn! workshop
  • Project team members and adjunct faculty attended HI-TEC
  • Faculty participated in Southeast Maritime and Transportation (SMART) Institute and Weld-ED training
  • ESCC leadership attended the Hurricane and Severe Storm Sentinel mission briefing on-site at WFF
  • Co-PI toured NIDA manufacturing facility and received training on use of equipment for CertTEC testing
  • Faculty attended ARRL Section Meeting
  • Co-PI attended faculty workshop: STEM Takes Flight in Virginia on-site at WFF
